question:
The torrid zone lies between _________.

SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024
option_1: Antarctic Circle and Tropic of Capricorn
option_2: North Pole and Arctic Circle
option_3: Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn
option_4: Arctic Circle and Tropic of Cancer
solution:
• The torrid zone is the region of the Earth that lies between the Tropic of Cancer (23.5°N) and the Tropic of Capricorn (23.5°S)
  • It receives direct sunlight throughout the year, making it the hottest climatic zone on Earth
  • This zone includes the Equator and spans regions in Africa, South America, Asia, and Oceania
  • The constant exposure to the Sun’s rays results in high temperatures and tropical climates

Additional Information:

  • The Earth is divided into three heat zones:
    • Torrid Zone: Between Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn (hot zone)
    • Temperate Zones: Between the tropics and polar circles (moderate climate)
    • Frigid Zones: Near the poles (cold zone)
  • Countries like India, Brazil, Indonesia, and Kenya lie partially or wholly within the torrid zone

question:
At what latitude does the easterly jet stream blow over peninsular India during the summer months?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The easterly jet stream that influences the Indian summer monsoon blows over Peninsular India at approximately 14°N latitude during the summer months
  • This Tropical Easterly Jet (TEJ) develops in the upper troposphere, especially during June to September, and plays a vital role in monsoon onset and intensity
  • It originates from the East African highlands and flows eastward across the Indian subcontinent, roughly along the 14°N parallel
  • This jet stream supports the low-pressure area over northwestern India, aiding in the inward flow of moist monsoon winds from the oceans

Additional Information:

  • The TEJ is strongest at an altitude of around 12–14 km
  • It is associated with the high pressure over the Tibetan Plateau caused by intense summer heating
  • The presence of TEJ is one of the key upper atmospheric indicators of a good monsoon season in India

question:
In which month is the Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) located around 20°N-25°N latitude (over the Gangetic plain) ?

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) shifts northward during the summer months due to intense solar heating in the northern hemisphere
  • By the month of July, the ITCZ reaches approximately 20°N–25°N latitude, lying over the Gangetic plains of northern India
  • This northward shift of ITCZ is closely associated with the onset and strengthening of the southwest monsoon over the Indian subcontinent
  • The convergence of southeast trade winds from the southern hemisphere and southwest monsoon winds occurs along this zone

Additional Information:

  • The ITCZ is also referred to as the monsoon trough when it lies over the Indian landmass
  • Its position fluctuates throughout the monsoon season and plays a key role in rainfall distribution
  • During January, the ITCZ lies to the south of the equator, and it gradually migrates northwards by June–July

question:
Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the Coriolis force?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: It deflects the wind to the right in the north and left in the south.
option_2: It is directly proportional to the angle of altitude
option_3: Deflection is less when the wind is high
option_4: It is absent at the equator.
solution:
• The Coriolis force is an apparent force caused by the Earth’s rotation, which affects the movement of wind and fluids
  • It deflects winds to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere
  • The Coriolis effect is absent at the equator and increases with latitude (i.e., as one moves toward the poles)
  • The magnitude of Coriolis deflection increases with wind speed, meaning higher wind speeds cause more deflection, not less
  • Therefore, the statement "Deflection is less when the wind is high" is incorrect

Additional Information:

  • Coriolis force is zero at the equator and maximum at the poles
  • It is proportional to the sine of latitude, not “angle of altitude”
  • It significantly influences wind patterns, ocean currents, and the rotation of cyclones

question:
Which is the Standard Meridian of India?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The Standard Meridian of India is 82°30′ East longitude
  • It passes through Mirzapur near Allahabad (Prayagraj) in Uttar Pradesh
  • This meridian is used to set the Indian Standard Time (IST), which is 5 hours 30 minutes ahead of GMT (UTC +5:30)
  • It was adopted to provide a uniform time across the country, avoiding time differences from east to west

Additional Information:

  • India spans nearly 30° of longitude, so without a standard time, local times would vary widely
  • The Greenwich Meridian (0°) is used as the reference for global time zones
  • IST is the time observed throughout India, despite the country's wide longitudinal extent

question:
Which is the waterbody that separates Andaman Islands and Nicobar Islands?

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Ten Degree Channel is the waterbody that separates the Andaman Islands from the Nicobar Islands
  • It lies at approximately 10°N latitude, hence the name
  • This channel is about 150 km wide and passes between Little Andaman (southernmost of the Andamans) and Car Nicobar (northernmost of the Nicobars)
  • It plays an important role in navigation and maritime boundaries within the Indian Ocean region

Additional Information:

  • The Eight Degree Channel separates Lakshadweep Islands (Minicoy) and Maldives
  • The Nine Degree Channel lies between Kalpeni and Suheli Par islands in Lakshadweep
  • The Eleven Degree Channel separates Aminidivi Islands and the rest of Lakshadweep
  • These channels are named after their approximate latitudinal position and are key to India's maritime geography

question:
Identify a factor that does NOT determine the temperature of ocean waters.

Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
option_1: Unequal distribution of land and water
solution:
• The temperature of ocean waters is influenced by several key factors such as latitude, ocean currents, and unequal distribution of land and water
  • Latitude affects solar heating—equatorial regions are warmer, while polar regions are colder
  • Ocean currents transport warm or cold water across oceans, influencing surface temperatures
  • Unequal distribution of land and water affects heat retention and distribution, altering regional sea temperatures
  • However, longitude (the east-west position on Earth) does not directly affect ocean temperature, making it the incorrect factor

Additional Information:

  • Other influencing factors include wind direction, depth of the ocean, and salinity
  • Eastern coastlines (in tropics) often have warmer waters due to warm currents, while western coastlines may experience cool currents
  • Temperature affects marine biodiversity, climate patterns, and weather systems

question:
Which of the following sets of statements are correct about Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) ?

a. The ITCZ is a broad trough of low pressure in equatorial latitudes.

b. This is where the northeast and the southeast trade winds converge.

c. The ITCZ is the equatorial trough normally positioned about 5°N of the equator and remains there throughout the year.

d. The ITCZ moves over to the plane of Ganga in Summer.

SSC CPO05/10/2023 (Afternoon)
option_1: Only a and c
option_2: a, b and c
option_3: Only b and c
option_4: a, b and d
solution:
Let’s evaluate each statement about the Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ):

  • (a) The ITCZ is a broad trough of low pressure in equatorial latitudes.✅

    ✔ Correct – ITCZ is a low-pressure belt near the equator where warm, moist air rises due to intense solar heating.

  • (b) This is where the northeast and the southeast trade winds converge.✅

    ✔ Correct – The ITCZ is formed by the convergence of trade winds from both hemispheres.

  • (c) The ITCZ is the equatorial trough normally positioned about 5°N of the equator and remains there throughout the year.❌

    ✖ Incorrect – While the ITCZ is often slightly north of the equator, its position shifts seasonally, especially northward during Northern Hemisphere summer.

  • (d) The ITCZ moves over to the plain of Ganga in Summer.✅

    ✔ Correct – During summer (June–July), due to intense heating over the Indian subcontinent, the ITCZ shifts northward and lies over the Gangetic plains, helping draw in southwest monsoon winds.

Hence, the correct set of statements is: a, b, and d

question:
During October-November, the apparent movement of the sun is towards the _____.

SSC MTS 18/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• During the months of October to November, the apparent movement of the Sun is towards the south
  • This occurs because the Sun moves southward from the Tropic of Cancer toward the Tropic of Capricorn as part of its annual apparent motion
  • This movement marks the post-monsoon or retreating monsoon season in India
  • It leads to the onset of winter in the northern hemisphere and a gradual drop in temperatures

Additional Information:

  • The autumnal equinox occurs around September 22–23, after which the Sun begins its southward journey
  • By December 21–22, the Sun reaches the Tropic of Capricorn (23.5°S) — the Winter Solstice in the Northern Hemisphere
  • This southward movement of the Sun also contributes to changing wind patterns and the development of northeast monsoon in Tamil Nadu and adjoining areas

question:
The southern part of India lies in the _________ belt.

SSC MTS 19/06/2023 (Afternoon
solution:
• The southern part of India lies in the warm climatic belt, specifically within the tropical zone
  • It is located between the Tropic of Cancer and the Equator, which ensures high temperatures throughout the year
  • This region experiences tropical climate characterized by warm weather, high humidity, and distinct wet and dry seasons
  • Therefore, the correct answer is (d) warm

Additional Information:

  • The temperate zone lies north of the Tropic of Cancer, covering parts of North India
  • The polar zone is located near the poles, far from India's geography
  • Though southern India receives ample rainfall, "rain belt" is not a standard climate classification term

question:
Tropic of Cancer (23°30′ N) passes through__________ state of India.

SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Tropic of Cancer (23°30′ N) is an important latitude that passes through India, crossing a total of 8 states
  • Among the options given, it passes through Chhattisgarh, making option (c) the correct answer
  • The Tropic of Cancer is the northernmost latitude at which the Sun can be directly overhead (during the June solstice)
  • It plays a significant role in climatic variation, marking the boundary between the tropical and subtropical zones in India

Additional Information:

  • The 8 Indian states through which the Tropic of Cancer passes are:
    1. Gujarat
    2. Rajasthan
    3. Madhya Pradesh
    4. Chhattisgarh
    5. Jharkhand
    6. West Bengal
    7. Tripura
    8. Mizoram
  • Punjab, Maharashtra, and Kerala do not lie on the Tropic of Cancer

question:
On which of the following two dates does the equinox fall ?

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The equinox refers to the two days in a year when day and night are of equal length across the globe
  • These occur when the Sun is directly above the Equator
  • The equinoxes fall on:
    • 21st March → Known as the Vernal (Spring) Equinox in the Northern Hemisphere
    • 23rd September → Known as the Autumnal Equinox in the Northern Hemisphere
  • These dates mark the beginning of spring and autumn seasons, respectively

Additional Information:

  • On both equinoxes, the Earth’s axis is not tilted toward or away from the Sun
  • Equinoxes occur due to Earth’s revolution around the Sun and are key astronomical events
  • Solstices, in contrast, occur on 21st June (Summer Solstice) and 22nd December (Winter Solstice)

Correct Answer: (c) 21 March and 23 September

question:
From the north most to south most

point of India, what is the extent of India?

SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The north–south extent of India is the distance from the northernmost point in Ladakh (near Indira Col in Jammu & Kashmir) to the southernmost point, which is Indira Point in the Nicobar Islands
  • This longitudinal extent measures approximately 3,214 km
  • This span influences climatic variation, day length, and sunrise/sunset timings across regions

Additional Information:

  • The east–west extent of India (from Arunachal Pradesh to Gujarat) is around 2,933 km
  • Total land boundary of India is about 15,106 km
  • India lies between 8°4′ N to 37°6′ N latitude and 68°7′ E to 97°25′ E longitude

Correct Answer: (c) 3214 km

question:
What is the zone between the arctic circle and north pole called?

SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The zone between the Arctic Circle (66.5°N) and the North Pole (90°N) is known as the Frigid Zone
  • This region experiences extremely cold temperatures due to the low angle of sunlight
  • It has long polar nights and polar days, where the Sun doesn’t rise or set for months
  • The Frigid Zone receives minimal solar radiation and lies in the high latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere

Additional Information:

  • Torrid Zone lies between the Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn – the hottest region
  • North Temperate Zone lies between the Tropic of Cancer and Arctic Circle
  • South Temperate Zone lies between the Tropic of Capricorn and Antarctic Circle
  • The Frigid Zones are found between Arctic/Antarctic Circles and the respective poles and are the coldest zones on Earth

question:
1° latitude is equal to approximately ______ km.

SSC CHSL 16/10/2020(Afternoon)
solution:
• 1° latitude corresponds to the distance between two lines of latitude that are 1 degree apart on Earth’s surface
  • Since the Earth is nearly spherical, the distance between lines of latitude is fairly consistent
  • The approximate value of 1° latitude = 111 kilometers
  • This is calculated by dividing the Earth's meridional circumference (~40,075 km) by 360°

Additional Information:

  • Latitude lines are parallel, so the distance between each degree remains nearly constant from the Equator to the poles
  • On the other hand, 1° of longitude varies by latitude: it is ~111 km at the equator but becomes 0 km at the poles due to convergence
  • These calculations are essential in geography, navigation, and cartography

question:
Lines joining located at equal travel time from a common centre are called:

SSC CHSL 21/10/2020(Morning)
solution:
• Lines that join places having equal travel time from a common center are called Isochrones
  • The term comes from Greek: “iso” = equal, “chronos” = time
  • Isochrones are used in transportation studies, urban planning, and geography to show accessibility zones from a specific location
  • These are often seen in commute maps, showing how far one can travel within a certain time by car, bus, etc.

Additional Information:

  • Isohalines: Lines joining points of equal salinity in oceans or water bodies
  • Isobars: Lines joining points of equal atmospheric pressure on weather maps
  • Isobronts: Lines connecting places where thunderstorms occur simultaneously
